Before posting a thread, please check our catalog to ensure that a thread about the same topic does not already exist.

AIM-9x Is all aspect as well has having dual band IIRCM optical tracking. Most 'Heat seeking' missiles have been all aspect since the 80s.

Most modern Fox 2s (Sidewinder M+, Magic II, R-73) are all aspect

You have Optical (IR and basic TV Contrast), Semi active radar homing (sparrow and such), and Active radar homing (Missiles have their own seekers for terminal guidance).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57135200

Russians unironically never had a chance to develop it. Until 1914, the country was under-industrialized to the point where the US had to start producing Mosin Nagants for them to equip the Imperial Russian Army. The Russian Civil War wrecked much of the infrastructure the nation did have. While there was industrialization of unprecedented scale under Stalin, the Red Army continued to lag behind despite developing some fairly impressive tech such as the SVT-40 and the BT and KV-series. Russia's next big fight was in 1941 and it was a total disaster, with the Red Army on the verge of total defeat, only being kept alive on life support by billions of dollars of everything from Spam to entire factories. From 1945 to 1979, the USSR did not fight a major war and logistics continued to remain on the back burner except for the occasional airlift. From 1991 onward, not only did the existing transportation system in the Soviet Union totally atrophy, but supply officers, who were never particularly well respected or paid made ends meet by stealing nearly everything that wasn't nailed to the floor and selling it on the black market.

Compare that to the United States. America has fought most of its wars on the other sides of the ocean, which by its very nature FORCED to develop a sophisticated network of logistics. Everything from rifles to tanks was designed to be stuffed into the holds of cargo ships and later aircraft in the largest numbers possible, and a complex system of cataloging and accounting for every piece of said equipment had to be devised.

While the Russians were still using horses to get supplies to the Eastern Front, Americans were building Liberty Ships in under a week for sport.

>>57136175
I have worked with the very rich and the very poor, the rich spend more on consumerism in general ($2k bottles of wine instead of $20 bottles) but spend a much smaller fraction of their income on consumerism because they can afford to.
For example a poor person earns $500 a week, they pay $200 in rent $100 on food $50 on bills $50 on fuel and have $100 left for whatever they want (generally booze / smokes / takeout). They have spent $100 (food) + $100 (luxuries) for $200 or 2/5th's of their income on consumerism.
When I was in the mines making $5,000 a week I would spend $200 on rent, $100 on food, $50 on bills, $50 on fuel and ~$200 on luxuries for a total of $300 a week but only 3/50th's of my income.

I find the guys on ~$200k - $1m are the idiots that act way richer than they are while the guys on ~$50m are over making a show of their wealth.

China has been interested in the Far East for a long time. First, it still legally claims some of Russia, and will have nationalists do some chest thumping occasionally about how it is legally part of China not Russia.

Second, it has moved a tsunami of Chinese into the area. There is only 7 million Russian citizens in the Far East but it holds a disproportionate amount of their natural resources wealth. That population is only half Russian at best. You have very large indigenous and Mongolian populations who have been targeted for conscription and have their own secessionist movements.

In 2000, the area had almost no Chinese. By 2014, it has 800,000 Chinese living in the region. They have taken over many of the natural resources extraction jobs. With the West pulling out with sanctions, China has gotten even more leverage on naming its own price to extract from Russia, using its own people and capital.

Chinese population figures for the Far East end in 2014 because Russia was butthurt about the stats and nationalists didn't like it, but they are probably close to 1/5th of the population now. Along with minorities, they would be close to half and control most of the extraction capital with the West gone.

China could very easily support an "indigenous" uprising in Russia. It won't because the obvious bigger prize / threat is using its massive influence to pick the next Tsar when Putin dies with no clear successor. The threat is an EU/NATO Russia on its door. China is content to just own the Far East's resources, but if a democratic reformer ever takes control, then they will likely try to pull it free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When loading pistol rounds does anyone else just scoop whatever powder you've got with each primed case and press a bullet in? Also, I've had great luck filling magnum rifle cases (like .300 win mag) with cheap pistol powder. Since pistols are tinier, the powder is tiny...but so is the tiny amount. That's 3 tinies. If you put tiny powder made for tiny guns in a big case made for big guns, it balances out. I've had really good results eyeballing powder amounts into cases with this understanding. With .300wm, for example, I can get a whole range of bullets to fly from 2500fps to 3900fps just by eyeballing and adjusting the powder level. All my loads shoot minute of whitetail at 30 yards, and that's all I'll ever need. If I wanted to try to shoot a deer further away I'd just bring more ammo (that I was able to reload like 3 times faster than those fudd manuals, btw).

Reloading is super easy if you just think about how things work instead of trying to read and follow 10 billion fucking instructions and lawyer warnings which I don't have time for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57121956
its effect on accuracy is due to its effect on the point in the barrel's harmonic movement the bullet leaves the muzzle. Barrels whip around a little when firing, like a tuning fork, generally tracing a figure 8, and accuracy means making the bullet leave the barrel at the same point on that figure 8 each time. The speed of the shockwave moving through the steel of the barrel is roughly 20x the speed of sound in the air, and it traverses the barrel up and back down it ~5 times before the bullet leaves the barrel, squeezing the bullet a little as it passes it. I've seen stuff suggesting you want the bullet to leave the barrel when the shockwave is at one end of the barrel or the other. If the barrel and its mounting were molecularly perfectly square with each other, you wouldn't get any lateral movement of the barrel from this shockwave, but machining methods are never perfect.

I haven't done this because I don't care enough, but you'd want to get a lot of brass from one manufacturer, gauge the neck thickness on all of them and discard any outliers, then anneal all the necks at a given temperature to give them all the same neck tension. Then you can start working to find your most accurate load for that rifle, redoing the annealing process every time you load a given case. If you're chasing accuracy that much, then you'd also be weighing your brass and discarding any outliers, to make sure they have as close as possible internal volume to each other, so that perfectly identical charges result in identical pressures and thus velocities, to make the bullet leave the muzzle at a repeatable point in the barrel flex.

>>57122585
The USN has been carrier-focused for over eighty years. Carrier-based aviation has been used in every major conflict the US has fought since 1945, from Korea and Vietnam to the Gulf War and the War on Terror. We're also one of the very few countries that have ever used carriers in battle. And the USN began planning for a naval war fought in the Western Pacific back in 1897. It only stopped being the USN's primary focus after they had wrecked the fleet of the sole unfriendly Pacific power so thoroughly that the surviving ships were almost a rounding error. In short, we're given this some thought and have had minor success in the past.
The US Navy currently has multiple classes of surface combatants that were designed for the sole purpose of defending carriers from air attack. Some of them can shoot down intermediate range ballistic missiles. The US Navy and Marine Corps have as many 5th generation fighters as China does in total. Our friends and allies in the Pacific means the USAF will have bases to operate from and the US Army will have sites to emplace ground-based air and missile defense systems.
If our war plans assume we can't operate carriers within range of Chinese aircraft and missiles, it's because if we can do it, we won't need that much of a plan really.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57125143
Volume of fire isn't really an issue if you look at other developments and initiatives.

UGVs becoming increasingly common means you have something that can carry a GPMG or grenade launcher, which can either find targets itself of be directed onto them and correct its fire autonomously.

Autonomous batteries and autonomous drone spotters mean fire missions can come far more rapidly, and with greater accuracy thanks to advances in munitions.

Autonomous 60-81mm mortars and field guns are probably more important. These can get filtered down to low levels and can provide organic fire support. It's much easier to provide rapid, organic support when some UGV can carry around mortars that can aim and fire themselves based on drone/soldier data. Loitering munitions offer another way for squads to receive support in terms of both recon and fire.

If you go up to 6.8mm but have autonomous mortars on your IFV, which can also drive itself and fire its autocannon at targets autonomously, and you have a little UGV carrying ammo for you with an automatic 40mm air burst launcher, your total fire power and suppression abilities are going way up, not down.

As to lines of sight, there are long lines of sight everywhere. Major roads have long lines of sight frequently. Just going to church, I go through plenty of stretches where you can see 1,000 yards or more out. Cities, which are increasingly where populations live, are full of very long lines of sight. At my old job I'd see out most of a mile from the parking garage I used down two major streets. From my office I could see out 800 yards east. It's not that cities don't have long lines of sight, they are just limited and there is tons of cover. I don't think you can really take advantage of 6.8mm in these enviornments because targets are flitting between cover at long distances. However, down the road smart scopes will probably make this feasible. The larger problem might be IDing targets as actually hostiles.

IDK why people obsess over the service rifle of all the things coming out anyhow. Point and click mortar targeting, where the thing aims, fires, and reloads itself and you can aim it from a tiny drone, and the modular system can be mounted so easily on vehicles - that's the cool/important thing.

Also they drones can circle for you without an operator and then flag potential threats for you, or call out ATGM launches to your AP systems. Especially cool with lighter than air systems that can stay up as eyes in the sky for threats/targets pretty much non-stop any time you are moving.

When you're less than a few hundred meters away, bullet drop is a practical non-issue. M855A1 zeroed at 50 yards out of an M4 is point blank out to almost 300 yards away. Within this range, bullet travel time for M855A1 vs 6.8 General Purpose can also be expected to be near identical.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57137726
>an M4 is point blank out to almost 300 yards away.
100-150 sure, not so much 300. With a 100 yard zero at 300 yards you'll have more than a full foot of bullet drop and beyond that it VERY quickly drops off so at 400 yards you've got like 3 feet of drop. At 500-600 yards you're dealing with 10-15 feet of drop.

Meanwhile the new 6.8x51 round has less than 10 feet of bullet drop out at 750 yards.

Also 6.8 should be less impacted by cross winds due to the higher velocity and higher mass bullet.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57137962
>With a 100 yard zero at 300 yards
I said zeroed at 50. But even with a 100 yard zero, M855A1 is point blank out to approximately 230 yards - still meeting and subjectively exceeding the definition of "less than a few hundred meters away".

>you'll have more than a full foot of bullet drop
No, it doesn't. Using a G7 BC of 0.154, a velocity of 2950 FPS, and a height over bore of 2.75 inches, bullet drop at 300 yards is estimated at 10.7 inches.

A 100 yard zero for a 0.49 G1 BC bullet at 2900 FPS and a 3.25" height over bore, approximating the 6.8 EPR round, yields 8.4" of bullet drop. If 5.56 is not considered point blank at this range with a 100 yard zero, then neither is 6.8.

It is extremely easy to correct for in both cases, computerized optic or not, as even miscalculating distance by 50 yards results in less than 4.5 inches of offset.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57126059
So your argument against Moras is fuddtardation? What does a €150 fudd blade do that a Mora won't? In that price range you are looking at pretty much identical steel (somewhere in the 12C27, 14C28N or N690/VG-10 range) with the same hardness (58-60 HRC), meaning it won't be any tougher as well as have the same edge retention.
Then the only thing that remains is ergonomics and handle material, both of which are great on something like a Mora Companion that has a nice soft rubberized, non-slippery grip that fills the hand well and causes 0 hot spots.

Compare that to the knife you posted; shitty stainless steel bolsters don't feel good under extensive use or in cold climates. Wood as a handle material is prone to swelling and rotting if it's not treated with some sort of oil that polymerizes (giving you the texture of literal smooth plastic that is a hundred times worse than a high-friction rubber grip).

MORAChads stay winning.

>>57136137
Okay here is what you do
Polish off rust
Take off oil with cleaning alcohol or break cleaner or paint thinner.
Heat up vinegar (the cheapest will do)
Put you rust free and oil stripped knife in a mug
Pour in the barely boiling vinegar
If you have done it right you will see bubbles stemming from a chemical reaction forming on the top.
Leave it till it bubbles no more (10 to 20 minutes or so)
You have now formed a blackish or grayish patina layer that will protect your blade from rust
Take out knife and clean it with paper towel
Oil it
Put it in sheath.
Thank me later

Weave tactics don't force a merge, they set the enemy up for a pass by friendly wingmen and take advantage of the M2's superior ballistics to make deflection shots. Finns aside, the reason Buffalo did bad had less to do with hardware more to do with:
a) Bongs lacking ANY radar cover over Malaya and Singapore, all spotting had to be done by human eye, meaning Buffalos would scramble and gain altitude with japs usually on top of them,
b) Far East being the dumping ground for second rate pilots and ground personnel with no experience in tropics, who also had 0 combat experience unlike the japs they were facing AND were somehow more arrogant about their supposed superiority,
c) Battle of England was in full swing thus it was top priority to keep experienced maintenance crews in UK,
d) Assload of management errors coming from RAF running the show in Malaya
>BUT NOOOOOOOO B-BRITANIA R-RULES THE W-WAVES ITS NEVER OUR FAULT WHEN WE DO BAAAD LET ME HOP IN MY SKUA A TRUE BRITISH PROJECT TO SHOW YOU HOW ITS DONE

Hardware wise Buffalos were messed with because the USN wanted more of everything on board with F2A-2 and F2A-3 which lowered its performance when it turned out there's also a limit on the types of engines you can put into an already bloated small frame. Bongs ended up with these. By comparison Finns got F2A-1, which while undergunned were swift light aircraft, which was the original idea behind the Buffalo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57097624
Depends. Do you plan on being in a burning building or vehicle? If so then polyester under armour style shirts aren't a good idea as a base (unless you like having a shirt melt to your torso, getting a massive infection, and spending a month in a burn unit living in an oxygen tent having your gooch skin grafted to your chest). If you're just gonna larp any generic polyester t-shirt should do as long as you've got someone competent doing the needle work.

Don't like melting? Well then it's got to be nomex. Oh wait you're gonna melt in the sun because fuck is everything made out of nomex hot to wear in the summer. That being said this is the most "realistic" option for a base shirt (since real combat shirts are going to be at least melt and drip resistant). IIRC some of the fuelers at battalion had the Massif Cool Knit shirts issued and they were ok. Fort Chaffee is 110f in the summer so wearing clothes at all is too hot.

Well what about cotton? Cotton is fine...Except if you plan on being in an area which may be rainy and wet and 50f or less? Cotton based shirts aren't your friend. When cotton gets wet it loses its heat retention properties and is a one way ticket to hypothermia. That being said cheap subdued colored cotton shirts from Duke or other companies are common and cheap. Every milsurp store carries them and you can get a ton of them for not much.

There is smart wool but I don't recommend that for any hot climate because you know wool is wool. For a winter weight uniform they'd be great. It's just fucking expensive.

General purpose bugout bag for shtf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57106658
60L ought to do it. You'll want:
> calorie-dense food
> rope
> small flashlight
> glow sticks
> lighters
> zip ties
> knife
> toothbrush
> compass
> IFAK
> emergency blanket
> sewing kit
> bandana
> map of local area
> fire-starter
> cloths pins
> LifeStraw
> braided cable
> propane stove
> trail marker tape
> spork multi-tool
> multi-tool
> automatic fishing reel
> spices
> pocket saw
> light cookware
> folding shovel
> ballpoint pen
> antiseptic
> antibiotics
> iodine water purification tablets
> multivitamin/mineral (not necessary if you're only out there for 2-3 days, but good to have, especially if you get lost or stuck.)
> .22lr pistol
> ammo
> slingshot
> poncho/shelter
> changes of clothes (socks in particular)
It sounds like a lot, but it can easily pack into a 60L or smaller bag.

How much do you want to spend? I really like the Steiner military and marine series for the money, especially if you find a lightly used pair or on sale. The 7x50 are probably the best balance of image and balance, the 8x30s which are good all-arounders since they're lighter and smaller. Also have a set of M24 7x28 by L3 which fit in a large pocket, but they have laser filters that distort color and a reticle that's pretty much useless. You can get a the Fuji version w/o that but they'll cost more.
This stuff applies to all brands though, might be best to just grab a cheap mid-magnification pair and consider what you like/dislike about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57106758
only cause you posted...
in your kit you have 3 water filtration tools.
>bandana
>lifestraw
>iodine tabs

you need 1, maybe 2.

think about it, 1st layer is the bandana. itll filter most debris. believe it or not, you can drink more water than you think.
2nd, iodine.
you're on the move. chug your water you got then fill it up through the bandana, drop a tab, keep moving.
3rd, life straw. what's the scenario you have time to use that thing? it's an emergency, i get that but it's 8in long. do you have the space and weight for the long march? you do you but there's safe and there's over kill.
in the SW i'd maybe get it since the lack of water and abundance of cattle but elsewhere? you've already made space for the fishing pole so water must be plentiful.

I'd first say drop the pole for a jar of peanut butter but 2nd is drop the life straw. you'll be fine with iodine.
i'd also say the fire starter should be a bic. little effort for hundreds of lights.
otherwise pretty solid.
a decent knife can be a pocket saw too.

>>57111633
No pole -- automatic fishing reel, yo-yo style. A hell of a lot smaller.
Peanut butter is a great idea. Also famine food like Twix Peanut Butter. (AFAIK, that's the candy bar with the most calories per ounce.)
I got some bic lighters in there alongside the fire starter.
You're right about the LifeStraw. You probably don't need it unless you plan on staying out for a really long time.
One thing I forgot to add to the list is a solar panel to USB charger. Could use it to recharge the flashlight, and you can bring a lightweight Kindle e-reader with you to kill some of the boredom. Very small weight/space penalty for both.

i've had so many issues with mine, when i got it i couldn't get it to cycle more than 5 rounds and found the gas port was clogged with a burr from the factory so i took a small file and cleaned it out then it worked semi normally but it would short stroke randomly so i had to put a booster on it and that fixed the cycling issues
then later down the road it started rusting, i had to use a brass brush and oil every couple months to stop it
then recently i had another issue with the shepherds hook popping out of place and letting the trigger pin walk, i had to replace it with a tapco trigger plate i had in a parts bin
also, because i have to oil it so much to keep it from rusting it's like shooting a blackpowder gun sometimes
overall, 4/10, but i got it when they were still $500-ish so i'll go fuck my face

>>57123936
> Idk how zastava did it but holy fuck is this think a tac driver.
short + thicc barrel and decent sight radius are a big help for accuracy. Also it is nearly impossible for Zastava to make them with canted sights because the front sight is part of the gas block and if it cants too much one way or the other then the piston wont go all the way forward because it will bind making the gun non-functional, meanwhile if they tilt the hinged dust cover too much either way it wont lock because it is hinged and fastened in place at the front and cant flex meaning it wont shut and will also be non functional so the M92/M85 design lends itself well to accuracy because it HAS to be assembled right in order to leave the factory (As opposed to WASR where they could mount the front sight upside down and the gun would still technically function mechanically speaking). It also helps that Zastava seems to actually center the front sight post into the front sight block (centered up and down, left to right) which is all it really needs since the rear sight has no adjustments aside from flipping between 200 and 400 meters.

The longer the AK the more leverage you get for bending or flexing things in such a way that harms accuracy even if a longer barrel should theoretically be more accurate. Also the AKM has a rather thin barrel relatively speaking with spaghetti harmonics that flexes a lot in use. That won't matter with single shots but it really opens up in full auto.

Thanks for reading my blog and I'm sure that I've upset someone so be sure to (You).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57123932
Judging by that price I'm guessing that you got one of the earlier M92's from around 2013 to 2015 right? I have one of those and it works fine but the Century M92's from that era were not nearly as refined as they are now. To get those old ones "proper" you typically had to remove the thread protector, install a muzzle detent kit (sold seperately), put on a booster (which you should always have anyways because its cool), install slightly longer RPK trigger pins (the standard ones were barely long enough and some people had them fall out of place into the receiver), replace the shepherd hook with a trigger retainer plate, and lastly install some sort of rear sling swivel. Then they were fine aside from the odd burr like you had in your gas port.

HOWEVER, since 2020 none of this has been an issue anymore since Zastava actually seems to listen to their customers. New M92 pistols are g2g out of the box and have the following features as standard from the factory now: bulged front trunnion and 1.5mm reciever (as opposed to the thinner 1mm reciever and thinner slab sided trunnion of the century imported M92's), chrome lined barrel (old Century ones are just nitrided), muzzle brake spring detent comes standard now, RPK trigger pins come standard now, trigger retainer plate is standard now, and they all come with a hole in the rear trunnion for a standard $10 quick detach sling swivel instead of having to buy a $35 third party sling plate like the originals needed.

All AK47's have gone up in price since 2020 but only the Zastava M92/M85 has actually added features to offset or justify its rise in price. AK's like the WASR 10 are still just a WASR 10. (The WASR 10 actually comes with worse furniture now compared to the older and much cheaper WASR 10/63's actually lol.)

>gas tube
Unless you are talking about a factory KAC upper, if you are using a URX4 on something you are putting together you will not have to use the special KAC tool to remove the gas system. The gas block can be removed with the rail on, in fact, it has to be. The rail is the barrel nut and it is installed first and then the gas block is slid over the barrel with the gas tube already installed. So removing the block with the rail on is a non issue.

posts.name: Gookfoot
posts.com:
>>57136690
hard to say. Brassfacts has said his held zero. I do hear about some cracking ala >>57136655
but it doesn't seem to be something that happens to all units. It just seems to be that the polymer in the somogear is much shittier than a real peq and won't stand nearly the same abuse. Also the factory mounting hardware (if you can call it that) is laughably bad, but luckily you can cheaply and easily swap it with better real peq hardware. The output of the somogear is bright af and the laser and illuminator are pretty clean. My friends have a few they got recently but probably not enough use on them for me to report on how they are long-term, but I plan on trying one myself when they restock. Another anon on here has a Laserspeed and says it's super solid, but it's almost $1000 and unlike the Somogear which uses crane style plugs uses it's own proprietary plug for tape switch stuff. As somebody who has a few PERST lasers and who's had to chop off tapeswitch ends to cut/solder shit I wasn't interested in yet another option with non-US standard shit, even if it is decent and more robust than Somogear.

>TL;DR version
>if you don't care about tape switch compatibility and/or don't mind cutting/soldering shit if need be to get US switches to work, pay the $800-900 for the Laserspeed as it's more robust.
>If you like the idea of a $250 full power peq clone that may need some hardware replaced and may not be super durable long term but uses crane style plugs and an intuitive mode switch/firing buttons, take a risk with the somogear.

>>57136836
technically the tritium only works at night. If you look through a tritium only illuminated model like a TA01 during the day, it will barely appear illuminated at all. Most other acogs use some type of alternative secondary illumination such as fiber optic (ie TA31) or LED battery powered (TA02) for daylight illumination. TA31s are TOO fucking bright during the day, like retina-searing bright. Most people actually tape over 3/4ths of the fiber optic to keep that shit down and rely more on the tritium. If you have a TA31 model with dead tritium and need nighttime use, in a pinch you could tape one of those mini chemlights to the top of the optic at the fiber and get some illumination in there for a while, or you could use >>57136832
pic related, although I think that thing is kind of stupid versus just doing the above fixes with tape.

I just feel like it's less likely to be true and circular.

Receivers, minus trigger LPKs, extensions, I have no problem with aero, they're in the sweet spot of decent QC, pricing, and customer service where if they do fuck the QC and send me shit I'm probably getting a good replacement.

posts.com: Ideally I want picrel, a 5.56 FABRL, with heavy for caliber bullets and 80kpsi pressure (or higher). Almost duplicates 6.8x51 trajectory. But that’s a little far out and prob won’t happen. But a 350 legend case, necked down to .224, using similar VLD bullets is doable. Can load it to the same pressure as m855a1.. and the legend case is slightly wider than 5.56, and it’s smaller taper gives it a lot more capacity up top. This is more than enough to offset the capacity loss by using a longer bullet.. This could be a nontrivial improvement over the 5.56 for almost no weight penalty, and no capacity penalty. Cant use existing mags cause of the taper but whatever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57134930
I know. The North Star of the design team was weight savings while maintaining trajectory of m193.. But you don’t have to do that. You can have BCs normally reserved for larger calibers by having a better form factor, and form factor is essentially free BC.. And the high pressure makes it so that the loss in case capacity isn’t too big a deal. It’s what would result if the Program were taking place today and instead of weight savings, the design team’s objective was superior performance to 5.56 without increasing weight or volume.

Now I’m not saying this is feasible to mass produce, but turned copper bullets are able to achieve a form factor of 0.8 with bullets around 5 calibers long. That’s only 1.12” long. A 70gr .224 with this form factor would have a G7BC of 0.25. That’s normally reserved for bullets in .264 caliber and up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57137496
>>57137523
I’m gonna be the autist here and say 7.62x39 compared to 300 blackout is not the apples to apples comparison. 300 blackout makes concessions in case length - and volume - for the ability to seat the really long bullets for subsonic shooting. 7.62x39 doesn’t have that constraint. A better comparison is 300 HAMR. Basically 300 blackout with a longer case and an ogive length comparable to that of light/supersonic bullets loaded into 300BLK. It outperforms x39.. It’s hard to find and expensive and doesn’t enjoy the same aftermarket support as 300 BLK, but there it is. It exists and it mogs and it ought to be mentioned in any discussion about alternative intermediate calibers where 300BLK is a contender.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

> The 300 BLK was an answer to a problem that didn't exist.

It obsoleted the entire category of sub-machine guns - whatever theoretical use case they still had following the ubiquitous adoption of assault rifles. It shares mags and a bolt face with 5.56, actually works in AR pattern rifles, and compared to x39, is a more efficient use of cartridge and magazine volume with its higher pressure and less tapered case.

posts.com:
The US army currently uses 3K M113's for the following: APCs, Recovery Vehicles, Ambulance, Mortar, Command Vehicle and Logistic Vehicles. A non-tracked vehicle can do all that, but tracked vehicles have some advantages over non-tracked vehicles so it just becomes and endless argument.

The second part, does an IFV like Bradley fulfill the APC role? I'd argue no. The M113 and the projected replacements hold many more fighters, Bradley, in order to fit the gun, has less. Unless you figure out a way to create space from nothing, I don't see how you can argue one replaces the other. Either you want to carry more troops (and the M113 is the better tool for the job), or you want to carry less troops but more firepower (in which case you need a Bradley). It is basically like arguing between a van and a truck. If you want to carry lots of people, a van would be better, if you need to move lumber, you'd want a truck.

It's better to just imagine IFVs as a sort of micro land carrier. While the dismounted infantry and their armaments are the equivalent of carrier aircraft. The IFV with it's sensor packages can detect threats from afar and direct the infantries. While the infantry can screen the surroundings and warn of the more immediate threats up close.

>>57135157
RAND came to much of the same conclusions, but with some caveats and additions:
>Tracked are better in bad terrain (but it is closer than some assume)
>Tracked are better if an ambush is a threat.
>Tracked vehicles allow for heavier and more powerful vehicles. If occupants were to fight mounted you NEED tracked for survivability in a modern battlefield because wheeled can't accommodate enough armour. Wheeled IFVs are likely a bad idea.
>Wheeled are faster on roads.
>Wheeled require less maintenance
>Wheeled will generally allow for faster travel to the battlefield
>Wheeled vehicles allowed troops to be better rested and suffer from less fatigue.
Basically wheeled IFVs are an inherently bad idea, but that the role of taking troops to-and-from a battlefield (or over long distances) is probably a better fit for a wheeled vehicle. All things we already knew. If we use Ukraine as an example. Driving from Kharkiv to Slovyansk? Wheeled. Driving from Slovyansk to Bakhmut? Tracked

>>57127440
NTA but it is pretty good. There is virtually no fancy tacticool shit like MR has, for example, but it is a nearly indestructible, oldschool top loader that is surprisingly pleasant to carry, even when overloaded. I know people who bought the backpack a decade ago and use it in their daily job (militaryfags), and it still looks nearly new (apart from shoulder straps getting a bit fuzzy on the surface). I can easily imagine that your kids could probably inherit the thing with little care. If you want a simple backpack that will probably outlive you and you don't need any fancy special functionality, go for it.
The only downside is a price, but again, one time buy item, and you are supporting a local binland business, not Chang's kid sweatshop.

>>57132339
3 day bags are closer to 30 liters. It'll hold your meals (which are assumed to be MREs), water (apart from the hydration bladder), water purification, your shelter, two shirts, two pairs of socks, and two changes of underwear. The rest is going to be carried by other means, like wearing it. A 3 day excursion is based on the assumption that you have something to return to at the end, but if you have to go a day without food because something went wrong you can.

>>57134182
Incidentally, the whole "eggs in a basket" should be a ready minder for anyone putting together a "bug out location." Burying portions of your supplies in 55gal drums or even those couple-hundred-gallon septic tanks would be a wise move. If you show up and your property is already occupied, you can assess your ability to extract a portion of your supplies and move on. If you're surrounded and forced to flee, you don't lose everything if the plsce gets torched or raided, and again, you may be able to return and gather some supplies. Caches don't just have to be guns and ammo, although they shouldn't necessarily not have some of those things as well. Burial below the frost line, appropriately sealed in mylar with O2 absorbers and dessicants would be a good method of storage for things like first aid supplies, basic/common drugs/otc-meds, in addition to dry food goods, tools, batteries, pool shock, salt etc.

>>57133864
Sounds like you should spend a decent amount of time and effort learning to get comfortable with camping in worse-than-ideal conditions, then some more-than-basic first aid and general communications knowledge (e.g. become a HAM, but not one of the old farts who hates digital modez), and learn to shoot halfway decently along the way. Getting in good shape wouldn't hurt either. Learning how to do some basic wiring, electrical troubleshooting and a little around the house/car maintenance and repair might be useful too. Suddenly you'll find yourself as a 35yo boomer with a couple hobbies. Focus on skill development first, then tailor your gear to your skillset. You can't carry a walmart on your back, nor can you (probably) afford to stock one in case shtf or the AYYYS invade or whatever.

I'm an Italian undergrad student who, for particular reasons I won't dwell on, wishes to immigrate to the US and make a career in its armed forces (preferably in either the Army or National Guard, preferably as an officer, and preferably still as Special Forces, but all that is beyond the point insofar as it doesn't matter for the answers to the questions I ask below).

As you may or may not know, legal immigration to the US is a pain in the ass unless you're lucky enough to have relatives in-country or a company willing to sponsor and pay for your permanent relocation, usually by virtue of quite exceptional job-related skills.

From what I can read online service in the US armed forces does help considerably with going from a green card to US citizenship, but to enlist in the first place you need to have a green card, and that's the troublesome part. I will contact a recruiter soon enough, but first I wanted to get any possibly useful info from you /k/ommandos, who hopefully won't (just) tell me to not come and to go back if I do as the stinky unwanted non-White wop that I am.

So, is there any way unknown to me in which the US armed forces can sponsor your green card as an employer or relative would? Can and do they help you in any other way to achieve your green card to make you available for service?

Any info even tangential to the questions asked is welcome. Thank you.

posts.name: Burt

>>57122808
>that explains it.
How do you figure?

The sight being centered in the slide doesn't correlate to accurate POI. You move the rear sight in the direction you want your POI to shift; your rear sight is to the right so it looks like it's already been corrected that way. If you're still shooting left it's either you or the sight needs to be moved even further right. Shoot the pistol from a bench rest.

It'll teach you sight allignment and trigger control (on a friendly trigger), but it won't teach you recoil control or how to not flinch, which are the two hardest things about shooting a real defensive handgun. I'd personally argue that its not more useful than dry fire, if your being honest with yourself. Now, as a plinker, for small game, or for handing something that isn't scary to a newbie, they are fantastic, but if you're serious about getting good with a handgun dry practice and live fire with that handgun are as good as it gets.

LEM is basically DA/SA. Except the first pull (DA) a two stage trigger. The first stage is basically just long trigger travel without any resistance. Until you hit a wall. Which is a light weight trigger pull.

That’s good for LEO because the long travel is your built in safety. 2. You can assess if you really want to shoot while taking that long slack out of the trigger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Previous >>56962567
Old Cover New Thread
Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>57028867
Tested the arc bridge last night, did a short sprint just to see if it will hold up from the position I set it to and it held up fine so far.
I decided to allow the bridge to do the widest FOV as it was very manageable to get the pano view to merge in my brain and man in it really is a nice feature to have when you are navigating, looking from a standard 40 degree bino setup at a few houses from the park roughly 50-75yds away I was seeing 3 houses and switching to pano FOV it allowed me to see about 2 houses extra to the left and right side, the blending of the two tubes is like looking at a venn diagram and it does take some time to get used to it for me it took about 10-20 seconds to adjust a bit of the arms to get the right position to allow me to get used to the merging of the images after that I was able to walk around like I normally can with mono or standard bino configurations.
I vastly prefer three arc bridge over the panobridge, it was simple to just pull apart the arms to get into pano view vs the panobridge requiring to get the right angle for both arms and it basically giving you unlimited adjustments it was harder to get the right placement and also it loosens over time quickly so you have to readjust quite often.
Using the Jerry-C/COTI was interesting, in the standard bino confusion the thermal overlay looked similar to how it looked in a mono confusion meaning my brain merged the two images. Once I set the pano FOV the thermal tube and non thermal tube split the display and my brain was able to tell the two tube display apart.
Unfortunately my NVGR recorder didn't record any video footage and I don't know why, I took out the sd card to see if there's any new video files and maybe the old video files that were already on there from a prior recording session caused it to not record as files existed already, but I deleted those files and did a simple test and the camera did record in that test, so I dunno.

Without taking it apart and checking the tube itself, it'll be hard to tell imo. If there is a DOM on the unit itself and its a later date production/manufacture i.e. when gen 3 was highly adopted, then maybe you can assume it is a gen 3 tube.
I know on the PVS-14 you can look at the eyepiece lens and turn the diaopter to a specific power value, for me its around -1.5 to -2.5, and look around at a specific angle to get the reflection hit the lens to see the intensifier model name, I'll try my best to get a picture of my tube through the eyepiece lens.
This image is pretty blurry, but it was difficult to get a picture of the model number but I was able to get like half of the "L3" logo and two letters of "Made in USA" text. posts.name: Poorfag Dualbandit
posts.com:
>Wraith wouldn't turn back on after being stored in the cold (15 degrees Fahrenheit at the coldest) after a failed coyote stake out.
>Fresh Energizer lithium batteries, stored alongside the optic. No power.
>Tried a USB power bank that I knew was good. No power.
>Brought it back inside, let it warm up and put in warm but not fresh cr123s. Oh hey it powers on.
Got a lolosun circle dot coming to replace it on my WASR.
I do like the Wraith, had a bunch of folks shoot with it over the weekend during the day. They all had a similar report, it is different but neat. I think it would be better on a softer gun than a 7.62x39mm. Gonna use it for my AR-15 build. Which I will hopefully get the parts for the upper ordered over the weekend.
Also, the SMSlaser from amazon is holding up well so far. The down and dirty splicing of an airshit tape switch hasn't failed or melted.
NGL, I want to get that Vulcan surefire head before attempting to replace the white light of the SMSlaser with an IR head. I really like how small the SMS is. It just has a few glaring problems preventing it from being a near perfect, civilian power MFAL.
>Swap the multi pin connector and tape switch for a proper Crane style plug receptacle.
>Replace the white light head for a focusable IR lamp or laser illuminator.
>Replace and/or relocate the on/off push button switch with a larger momentary only.
>Replace some of the settings on the selection dial to reflect the replaced white light. Don't need an IR strobing weapon light, IMO.

posts.com: The Pard NV007A came in. It works really well as a digital night vision device. Obviously it needs an IR illuminator to be useful. The built in one is fine, but the separate one I ordered that has a focus ring works better. I haven’t had a chance to see how it works as a sight. I have noticed the reticle isn’t perfectly centered with the clip on. Idk how this will affect accuracy, but I’ll find out. It has some neat features like being able to record your shots as well as a jack for a microphone and the ability to synch audio to the video. It can also record in color with enough white light. It also automatically adjusts the frame rate based on how much IR it is receiving. I guess this was done to improve performance in low light, but it’s honestly kind of annoying. It has a QD feature. You clamp the sleeve to the scope, and the clip on attaches to the sleeve with some lugs and a latch. It seems to be worth the $220 I paid for it. The sensor is far and away better than the night fox cape. The screen resolution is also much higher, and when there is plenty of IR it appears to have a much smoother image even though the manual lists it at 30 fps. I wish Pard would make a head mountable monocular with this sensor, screen and a flood illuminator. I would pick it up asap at this price point. Finally, unlike the nightfox it can pick up vis lasers no problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57093744
>0 and 1 tubes require an insane amount of light. even bright moonlight isnt quite enough
Gen 0 required IR floodlights. Gen 1, however, does work by bright moonlight. In Vietnam it required the cascade tube design. Today it only requires 1 tube. But I think you're still right because while gen 1 does work and show you more than you can see under a bright moon, it's no where near as bright as gen 2/3. Gen 3 has to dial back (gating/ABC) under bright moon conditions, and is still incredibly bright.

>>57113495
Depends what you mean by "primary" here. I know that the G3 and it's derivatives form a sort of separate family of their own (which I personally assert can be further traced back to the StG 44 as the "patriarch" of this family, but that's another argument), but I'm not so sure they can be considered a "primary platform" if you're referring to pure market relevance in the present day. I don't really know of many countries that still use G3/CETME derivatives today other than Turkey.
The AR-18 and it's derivatives are somewhat popular as a third option, usually in the form of a clone produced by a poorer country. In fact, I don't recall if any nation adopted the actual AR-18 itself, I think they all just made knockoffs that were slightly different. I believe Mexico's current service rifle is based off the AR-18, despite it's outer appearance looking more like a G36 (which itself is sort of based off the AR-18 anyway, so whatever).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57113495
Realistically, you have longstroke pistol (arguably M1 Garand/AK derived), shortstroke piston (AR18 derived), direct impingement (AR10/ar15 derived), and roller locked (STG 45/HK derived).
Roller delayed is pretty much just HK shit, current production longstrokes at this point are just AKs and m1s, DI is pretty much just AR15s and AR10s, and shortstroke piston is everything else. All the current development worth talking about is shortstroke.

Depending on what you mean by primary, there's shit like straight blowback and long recoil, but those aren't really made with normal rifle calibers in mind. You start getting into really niche shit after that.

posts.com: What is a match barrel? Why would I want one over a regular one?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57120001
unlikely to be made in the 1940s, as the company was dissolved in 1931 and moved into Savage/Stevens.
Here's some articles about similar pieces:
https://www.fieldandstream.com/blasts-from-past-american-gun-company-12-gauge-shotgun/
https://www.gunvaluesboard.com/american-gun-company-new-york-sxs-12-gage-hammer-gun-30483018.html
https://www.shotgunworld.com/threads/american-gun-company-12-gage-double-barrel.268731/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57120720
a match barrel is supposed to be more accurate than a standard barrel, and it is usually heavier. you would want it, as the name implies, for precision shooting in a shooting match.
It also really depends on what rifle or pistol you are using whether it is worth the additional cost and weight.
match barrels are often not chrome lined, because chrome lining can affect the accuracy of the barrel and even though modern techniques can eliminate that to a greater or lesser extent, the marrket (fuddlore) says don't chrome line match barrels, so people don't. They are often made from stainless steel to compensate for this.

The FAL is a shortstroke piston operated gun, the first of which made at any real scale were the SVT40s, also in SKS' and MAS 49s.

There was a few .280 British prototypes that FN made along with the British after WW2, some were bullpups, but none were ever adopted and they all turned into the FAL.
There's not really anything 'pre-war' that the FAL is derived from, its all 40s and later. I mean, some of the concepts and principles it uses existed before then, but not at any scale worth mentioning.

>>57137019
>doesn't own the gun he wants to modify
>doesn't know how to inlet or carve a stock
>Likely doesn't know where or how to source a piece of wood with the right grain for a basic-bitch gunstock let alone a jezzail
I mean, there's not much to work with here my dude. As a freebie, search for "stock inletting" tutorials. It's easy once you understand wood grain, marking, and the absolute necessity of keeping your chisels and gouges shaving-sharp. It's just slow and sweaty work, especially on a long stock. And that wood is going to be expensive as fuck. You should probably get a black powder Kentucky Rifle kit to practice with before committing to a full bolt-action jezzail conversion. Fortunately a gun with a busted stock is going to be a lot cheaper than an intact one, and you're at least not going for the meme "I'll restock and then flip it!" retardation.
I'm not trying to shit on you for having the idea, and I hope it goes well for you. Post pics once you start.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57137515
It's the
>carve a stock
bit that's important there. You need a long, relatively straight-grained chunk of hardwood with a curve at one end. The best stuff for gunstocks is the base of the trunk, in an area that's often damaged by commercial felling techniques, and it's best to work with riven or quarter-sawn boards rather than the standard sawing techniques. Your carving proper will have a lot less room for error compared to just inletting some parquet-work for a table and fucking it up is very expensive. Fortunately you're sourcing and seasoning your own wood, that's gonna help a lot on the price front.
The area where the stock interfaces with the breech has to be designed to hold up to recoil, which varies from gun to gun. The huge drop in the jezzail stock is really cool but it makes calculating that a pain in the dick.

Hence why I suggested looking up videos specifically about inletting gunstocks and buying a cheapie Kentucky Rifle kit. It'll help build the skill set you need to do the job with a raw hunk of wood. Especially since seasoning a stock blank -- even with a kiln on hand -- is gonna take a long-ass time.

>>57120172
Peak oil is kind of wishy washy, because it depends on the economic viability of proven reserves and that changes as technology is developed, both to make it easier to extract the oil and to get more effective value out of it.
Oil back in the 1930s was way easier to access compared to today, but oil is still affordable because of the vastly improved productivity of the oil industry and society generally.

We could run into peak oil sooner or later, but it's hard to predict exactly when because of these moving targets.
I would Argue that moving to renewables is likely to actually make peak oil happen sooner, as less money will be spent on the technology and infrastructure for oil production.

T1 stable unadjustable production your nuclear and coal to some degree.
T2 unadjustable unstable production this is your solar wind
T3 Stable adjustable this is your fossil fuels and hydro.
T3 can be shut off when T1 and T2 exceed total demand and turned on when demand exceeds T1 and T2.
Other issue is when T1 and T2 exceed demand you have to dump excess power somewhere or you will damage shit. (this is why the entire ukraine grid goes offline during attacks if they blow a transformer and demand drops sudden overproduction will cause a the overvoltage will fry shit)

>>57120133
Oil is not a primordial element like Lithium. The reason we use fossil fuels stem from their qualities as energy density and practical handling/distribution characteristics, moreso than their availability.
Chemical processes to turn biomass into fossil fuel analogues exist already, the reason that these are not our primary source of fossil fuels is their cost - a figure owing to both technological limitations and energy requirements. Established oil extraction infrastructure simply makes natural deposits cheaper. For the moment. We will not run out of fossil fuel the same way you run out of gas on the high way. Oil and gas deposits are discovered continuously, but what deposits are targeted for extraction depends on their accessibility. How expensive extraction will be in comparison to projected production. Naturally the most easily accessible deposits are ones to be utilized first and new technology constantly allows for previously economically unviable deposits to be accessed, but we extract at a higher rate than the technology develops. All this in a nutshell means that fossil fuels won't blink out of existence like a black man being told he's gonna be a dad - they will just become increasingly expensive untill a different fuel type is the better option.
This will not necessarily be hydrogen or li-ion batteries, their current use in western countries are the result of public perception of what climate-friendly technology looks like and a low cost stemming from (in comparison to conventional fuel) low proliferation. Remember when used the term "Primordial element" about lithium? Yeah, we won't be getting more of that stuff outside particle accelerator byproducts any time soon unless a new Big Bang comes around and entirely eliminates our shortage of anything at all all-together.
The way things are trending ATM there's good chances well just get better and better at making our own gas from vegetable biomass untill it's practically superior.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57135737
Faulty framing, selective inaction is valuable in espionage.

Let's say you knew with certainty you detect 100 balloons deployed against the country each year: if you're the president and want to counter espionage, how many should you destroy?

There's pros and cons to lots of answers.
>0
Gives away zero information including how much info you have. Saves, work saves money, saves relationships.

>1
Lets you study one, sends a signal you can and will shoot them down. You can pretend publicly it was a coincidence

>like 5ish but tell them directly to stop sending more
Signals more strongly that you're not going to tolerate balloons. Limits your operational expenses and conflict. Limits information your enemy has about your detection ability and response time, making changing up harder. If you recover at least 3, lets you get an average of what you expect to see on a balloon by giving you balloon samples for comparison.

>Like 10-30, but only the ones in important areas of the country
Lets you pretend you didn't see the other 70, sends incorrect signals to the enemy (they only detect them "here"), denies the enemy the high value intelligence that justifies sending more balloons in the first place, increasing the odds they stop naturally.

>50 of them, chosen at random
Limits sigint while also forcing the Chinese to do work to figure out how and why THESE were the found balloons.

>Like 80ish but leave 10-20 and do stuff on the ground in the remaining areas to fuck with Chinese data
Giving them bad data can be more valuable than preventing any data transfer

>Like 99 but fly a droneswarm up with a taunting message to the cameras on the remaining one
A show of force and operational awareness can potentially intimidate adversaries away from courses of action better than any political measure can

>100
reduces intelligence gathering as much as you're capable, but gives away 100% of what you can and can't detect, so the next balloon generation may elude you

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57136296
>It's laziness to not shoot them all
No retard, pay attention; selective inaction is valuable in espionage, often in literal "money means something" terms.

First, because your information is valuable. You leak a lot of information about your military doing this. Those operations would tell the Chinese a lot about US military air response capabilities, immediately give them the key for avoiding US detection with small aircraft by seeing what balloons the US missed besides the detected 100, and disproportionately wastes military time and money. It still might end of the day be worth it to shoot them down, but if you're a real military you need to think a lot harder about that cost-benefit tradeoff than
>stop being lazyand fucking do it.

Second, because cost asymmetries literally collapse empires, and balloons are a cost-asymmetry nightmare. Doing back of the envelope cost map link related at https://www.popularmechanics.com/military/aviation/a41956551/cost-per-hour-to-fly-us-military-aircraft/, it says launching a US aircraft is about 20k-100k per hour of flight time. Add refueling, munitions cost, ground and air crew time and pay, officer pay for coordination, lost time writing reports and pushing papers, plus general stupidity, delays, and budget overruns, it's likely all told 100k per mission to shoot down a single balloon. In this scenario, you're proposing we spend 10 million dollars on shooting down balloons that probably cost them 30-40k to make in total - plastic, cameras, and lighter-than-air gas are cheap.

JUST shooting down balloons in this model would therefore mean you're essentially telling the Chinese
>I'm going to give you a button that lets you turn spending $400 of your money into spending $100k of ours.
This is unironically the kind of shit we did to collapse the Soviet union during the cold war, that kind of asymmetry isn't sustainable. A military's not being lazy by choosing not to get baited.

>>57137056
>the balloon situation has the potential to create an issue like this for the US.
It's more likely to get us to pump money into developing air defense systems that have the same (or greater) capabilities, but a lower cost. The Gulf War sold the public on guided weapons but the War on Terror convinced us of the need for cheap guided weapons. The taxpayer was fine with paying for Paveway IIIs when the military used them on Iraqi radar sites. If the Air Force dropped one every time four or five Afghan tribesman with AKs showed up, Congress would cut the USAF's shiny toy budget to pay for it. And using stingers for SHORAD was fine when the only targets were manned aircraft but the Army couldn't fire one at every cheap quadcopter someone bought off amazon. Not unless they wanted the Next Generation Combat Vehicle to get cancelled on cost grounds. Now we have Stryker-mounted death rays.
If anything is going to get us to replace the Ticos, it's a vague threat that can enter US airspace in unpredictable locations, but which we know has to cross the Pacific in order to get here. And once we detected them, we'll need a surface-to-air weapon we could afford to use on fucking balloons. Xi might have unintentionally made us build the very weapon we'll one day use to counter Chinese missile spam.

Steel doors inside to give you time to react, and escape routes.

The best is old brick buildings built touching each others, where you can just buy the closest appartment in the other building and open a hole in both walls.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57126889
The only really big thing that differentiates the Elcan SpecterDR from traditional prism scopes, in terms of fundamental construction design elements, is the rotating internal demagnifier in front of the main prism. I don't know how that meshes with internal adjustments, but there aren't really many parts in the scope, though I imagine that the parts that ARE there require some particular advanced engineering to make them work successfully.

At any rate, the fixed power C79 and M145 came out before the SpecterDR did and they also have external adjustments, so I suspect this was a deliberate design decision that they would have made regardless. There are some advantages in the SpecterDR's case (not exactly sure about the other Elcans). The adjustments are quite thick and beefy, and they're buffered with springs which helps them absorb shock and essentially allows the optical unit to flex under impact and return to zero. The side effect of this is that they appear to weather repetitive vibration from such things as SCAR-Hs and belt feds very well, although that might be primarily because of all the fucking armor they put on it.

Also, this ensures that the scope maintains its optical centerline and alignment regardless of how far it's adjusted in any direction, whereas
increasingly moving the lenses more via internal adjustment can theoretically degrade image quality.

>>57127118
>aims at the legs to avoid a kill shot
LMAO yeah I'm definitely gonna blow a 5 inch hole in someone's leg with a TMK so I can nonfatally disable someone.

The solution to this is to not press on the scope while you're shooting (this would be true for literally any optic since metal itself has some flex to it) and make sure you don't leave twigs in your scope. I have an Elcan and I simply don't see this as an issue because the situations where it would be a problem are incredibly circumstantial.

>muh mud, muh ice
Since the lever is under spring tension and naturally rests in its correct 1x zero position via a detent, if mud and ice was making the lever stick in its place, all it would really do is prevent you from switching the magnification to 4x until you get the lever unstuck. Now technically it is not impossible for some tiny rock to work itself in the external adjustments, or around the lever assembly in a way that prevents the demagnifier from settling in its correctly zeroed position when switched from 4x to 1x, but again: see incredibly circumstantial (since these scopes have been used in many, many places with tiny rocks and this doesn't seem to be a remotely common issue).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57127664
>and the flip-in prism reduces it
To the best of my knowledge, it is not any kind of prism at all, simply a series of demagnifying lenses that sit in a rotating module. The only actual magnifying prism is the base 4x magnifying assembly that sits behind them.

i.e. Hoplopfheil is incorrect, it is not 2 prisms, simply one fixed prism and an internal magnifier that can rotate as needed.

>That's why the parallax isn't perfect on the lower power
The parallax on 1x vs 4x is different, but this is not generally a bad thing. At 1x it's set at 70m, and at 4x it's set at 150m.

Since shots taken at 1x are likely to be closer to 70m than 150m, and the reverse is true for 4x, this is likely to reduce functional parallax offset in practice. Not that 1x parallax is likely to be a big deal regardless, however it is a nice feature to have.

>and also why it lands on a slightly different spot every time.
On a molecular level I'm sure it does. I haven't found any meaningful POA shift in practice, and the testing protocol they go through before they're sold involves using laser collimators to check that the 1x and 4x zero are the same, putting the scopes through temperature and shock testing, and then checking the zeros again to ensure they have been maintained.

I considered multiple different general purpose AR optics, price being no object, before settling on the Elcan. Including offerings from the 3 companies you mentioned as well as others (e.g. Kahles, Vortex, Trijicon, Leupold).

>S&B Dual CC
Neat piece of engineering but the dual focal plane technology is simply unnecessary for 99.99% of 5.56 carbine things. Also fun fact, according to basic parallax calculations, the 10m parallax setting on 1x should actually *increase* parallax error in many situations.

>Swarovski
Z6i isn't known for durability. Neither is the sister K16i scope, really, but they ruggedized the K16i in comparison for a reason. The reticle options also largely kinda suck.

>NX8
Bleh eyebox, unexceptional optical performance by most accounts, main draw is its large range of magnification for its footprint which I simply don't see as being needed for an M4-type build.

>but Elcan eyebox is bad!!!11!!1
Elcan eyebox is awesome, just have to know how to set eye relief properly.

>ATACR 1-8x
Besides the small 1x FoV coupled with significant ocular occlusion, it lacks any notable flaws, however I would rather optimize my 1x and 4x than incur extra weight for more magnification.

Also, while the upcoming Primary Arms battery cap could change things up a bit, most other variable magnification scopes simply don't have the battery life and/or illumination system I'm looking for. The Z6i actually manages this very well but it's not worth all the other potential disadvantages in my eyes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57129300
Eye relief, eye relief forgiveness, and eyebox are all different things.

Eye relief is simply the distance you have to be from the scope to get full FoV. You adjust for this by moving the optic on your rail as necessary to accommodate your LOP. You do not stick the optic in any random position and force your face to move to it. Once your eye relief is set up properly, no distance is particularly better or worse than another, discounting the extremes.

Eye relief forgiveness is how far your eye can move forwards or backwards before you start losing FoV. I find the Elcan to be relatively average in this respect, better than the TR25 Accupoint and worse than the TR24, approximately equal to the Razor Gen 3 1-10x. Frankly I do not generally notice this dimension of scope performance much unless I am deliberately trying to evaluate it, as I simply don’t move my head forwards and backwards on the stock very much.

Eyebox is how much you can move off center when you’re at the correct eye relief before your image blacks out entirely. The Elcan beats all the 1-6x LPVOs I’ve looked through here, although it’s about average for 1-4x LPVOs. (1-4x and 1-8x LPVOs have a lot more more variance in eyebox in general whereas most 1-6x LPVOs seem broadly similar in this respect.)

I suspect most people who think the Elcan’s eyebox is bad do not know how to set eye relief correctly. This really goes for most people in general as most LPVOs are also set up incorrectly (if anyone says their eye relief changes when they zoom in, there is a high likelihood they have their eye relief wrong), but the Elcan in particular has some quirks that make people more likely to compromise their eyebox.

>Assault along the width of the line
>If a breakthrough occurs in one area, flood forces through that line and "blossom" outwards behind the enemy lines in several directions (we saw this on something of a decent display with Poposna, albeit for little long-term benefit).

The problem here is even if a breakthrough is achieved in the south somewhere, it's *a lot* of wishful thinking to expect whatever forces are down there would be enough to develop a breakthrough in such a way that it would demand the pulling of Ukrainian troops from other fronts to contain it. Ukrainians have shown themselves to be pretty well buttoned-up on the southern and Donetsk fronts.

I think that's the overall issue Russia is facing right now. There really, really seems to be a lot of unironic coping and wishful thinking fueling their strategy at this point, more so than at any point in the first 8ish months. Not a good sign for their prospects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57118655
I c

I haven't messed with PSUs but am hoping to grab a spot at one when i switch to the reserves. A few people at my unit have prior PSU experience. They say it's a lot of standing security watches where nothing happens. But also some legitimately interesting drills, training and fieldwork. ME's in waterside security do noncompliant pursuit gunning and shoreside security MEs train doing land nav, diet infantry tactics, and MOUT. No law enforcement potential either way if that is/isn't your thing. The biggest draw for me is that they're reserve-only units, so everyone shows up on the same weekends. It's more of a family and the world doesn't keep spinning without you. Rumor mill says no more extended deployments to cuba.

On the other hand sector MEs are more chill. But you'd be a reservist in a mostly active unit, and you'll have some awkward downtime where the command isn't quite sure how to make use of you. You would expect to integrate the sector's full-time boarding team, basically an recallable swat team, and get pulled to do security boardings on big ships. And also train others in LE.

Either way good luck and have fun

>>57121414
>In some ways having an aviation background can be less desirable,
This is false, they like to see people with an aviation background and it will help you with selection as well as flight school. That being said, the majority of pilots I know didn't have any aviation experience prior to joining, so it's not like it's a prerequisite.

Additionally, each Street to Seat board puts emphasis on different portions of the packets that they're sorting through. They're given guidance from the Pentagon that changes every other month, so one month it will be "hey we want you to select more people that have private pilots licenses" and then another month it will be "hey we need dudes with good ACFT and SIFT scores" etc...
>>57108648
All you neeed for LORs is a point of contact for one or two aviators that you can meet. I have friends that got some pretty crazy LORs just from reaching out.
>160th SOAR CW5 LOR from messaging the dude on LinkedIn
>tons of CW4 LORs from just hitting people up on facebook
Just call ahead and show up to your closest aviation unit to chat with aviators and ask to an get LOR at the end. Most people are pretty open to helping you out so long as you aren't a completely irredeemable sperg (and this is coming from a pretty big autist).

Try not to make all of your LORs be from people that you don't know, and don't be afraid to write up your own letters that you can give to people that they then sign off on. I did this for two of mine, one of which was an O-8. It's a pretty well accepted way of doing things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57108494
the only thing that kept the P51 from serving to ad infinitum is the fact it was designed too early to benefit, and any close equivalent was designed too late.

notable features of the P-51:

>piston engine
this is by far the most limiting factor, if it was a turbo prop, it could have had a longer lifespan. we eventually did get some close equivalents but they too had "fighter pilot" disease.

>high central canopy.
the placement of the canopy is the main reason for it not having extended life. as a fighter aircraft with a sort of "tunnel vision", and using the guns approach this is actually just fine. for a ground attack aircraft this is very bad. you need to see what you are going to shoot at. later planes solved this by either using a camera, or moving the cockpit forward to the nose. Basically the P-51 lacked awareness off the end of its nose. this is symptomatic of prop-fighters as the propeller is a major issue to work around. this is why the F-4 got pushed into attack roles and most fighters are labeled multi role, because the jet engines allow for a high-forward cockpit which is good both for general observability and ground attack. however with the installation of camera assisted awareness, none of this really matters anymore.

>STOL
the P-51 can ostensibly take off from a relatively short runway. much shorter than most modern war planes, particularly jets. it can also take off of hard-packed dirt runways, which most jets cannot.

the nail in the coffin is that the US military needed a harder hitting plane. the P51 was upgraded to the limit of its serviceability, but the dynamic of air-combat evolved so sideways and quickly that the P51 was left as a relic almost immediately following WWII. It lacked the speed to perform air dominance, it lacked the design to perform CAS, and it was too small to be of use as Cargo or Recon. so when the jet opened up options it was quickly relegated to being a trainer or supporting roles it wasn't designed for.

>>57108908
the Soviet armored fleet is actually more intuitive and well designed that an outside observer might think.

the recent war has showcased how the soviet approach to warfare is highly favorable for its own self defense of offensive capabilities.

the main reason for this design philosophy is because of the limited mobility of the Soviet military. they focus on rail logistics for a reason. they have a lot of land and a hard time moving forces to get there. so three things occured to the russians:

>why not give infantry their own mobile bunker.
>carry everything you need with you.. on the vehicle
>Armor is the spear point of a military formation.

these fundamentals are the basis of mechanized infantry existing WWII. if one observes the soviet military and doesn't account for the evolving battlefield, the soviet designs make a lot of sense for the last war they fought, being WWII. since they did not perform a lot of land wars against peer or near peer adversaries, nor did they believe in technology over-match. Their equipment constantly became more and more retrograded by the American/western counterpart. as a result of a lack of innovation while very capable based on last generation technology, the Russian evolution of soviet designs are either way too expensive to outfit enough forces to make a significant difference without burning through the fleet immediately. OR, are older-designs that are still considered good enough with some minor and often low cost solutions.

the Russian military is still very centralized and as a result, there is very little competition to improve designs and so innovation is either stalled or often predatory (stealing concepts from western competitors). they same could be said of their closest peer, however the chinese actually have adapted and were in a place to not suffer from the soviet stagnation. the CCP's regression has resulted in the starting to pick-up those bad Russian habits of predation of western innovation.

>>57119140
Both are correct.
The Sherman had highest crew survivability rating losing less men per knocked out tank compared to its contemporaries.
The Sherman initially had a burn rate of about 60-80%, which by the way is similar to the Panzer IV and Panther and Tiger etc.
However they removed the ammo stored in the hull sponsons and moved all of it to the floor of the tank, which is the lowest point of the tank and least likely to be struck.
Also, they introduced wet stowage.
The ammo was in wet bins surrounded by a Water-Glycol mixture which not only would put out and dampen any fire, but reduced spalling.
All of this got the Shermans burn rate down to 15%, while tanks like the Panther, Tiger I, T-34 were all still in the 70-80% range.
You can cope all you want germoid, the German tanks sucked and the American tanks were the best in the war.

Higher volume of fire (200 20mm rounds Vs 1500 .50) mean more hits in practice, and convergence could be set up in many different ways.

You had to get very close for convergence to be a serious issue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Main problems with the Panther in combat was it's poorly designed optics setup and slow turret traverse rate.
For some reason, standard German practice was to not give the gunner a high FOV periscope, so, when combined with the slow turret traverse rate, it was difficult for the gunner to rapidly acquire and engage targets, even those spotted by the commander.
A Sherman gunner could engage a target spotted by the commander in practically half the time.
In the chaotic close quarters fighting In north-western Europe this made a big difference.

Otherwise the panther had poor operational availability due to being rushed into service, and problems with the drive chain never being properly fixed, as a result of a reluctance to disrupt production.
It was also a needlessly large and heavy tank due to some outdated design decisions, having a radio-man and a front transmission.

Being made from wood doesn't necessarily make you flimsy, but it was more of a cost saving measure than a performance one.
The Soviets also made heavy use of wood composite, but generally switched more and more to Duralumin as the war progressed.

The main problem with the He-162 wasn't so much the wood, but the glue, which wasn't properly tested and actually degraded the structural properties of the wood at the joins, resulting in aircraft falling apart mid-air.

It wasn't the introduction of the P-47, it was the much-belated introduction of drop tanks and new escort doctrines, both of which were directly opposed by the same USAAF generals who kept pushing unescorted bombers into ruinous engagements. The Mustang was certainly handy, and burned less fuel for the same trip than the Thunderbolt, but it wasn't the revolutionary war-winner it's been claimed to be.
