>>57126227
>P-47s had the ability to go to Berlin

Most planes of the era (ex. P-38) could go to Berlin with big enough drop tanks, going to Berlin and coming back however was reliant on actually being good at the air superiority escort role which the P-47 wasn't. The Mustang had a 11:1 aerial kill ratio against the Thunderbolt's 4.3:1 and the Thunderbolt was inferior in every metric of air-to-air combat except climb rate. Most of its aircraft kills were on the ground. The vast majority of American aces got their kills in P-51s and the majority of allied pilots strongly preferred it when asked about the two types in post-war interviews while German pilots overwhelmingly feared the P-51 more. There's a good reason the P-47 got replaced. You can argue that it made first contact with the enemy and was more important to the pre-1943 air war but it certainly wasn't a better fighter or more suited for that role. The Mustang was also 20-30% cheaper to mass produce than the P-47 and far more fuel-efficient.

>The P-47 fought the Luftwaffe at the height of its strength and was instrumental in crippling its supply of well trained pilots.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57127004
Weight and balance with the heavy powerhead is the main problem. Professional lightweight bars can help get the 30"+ cutting lengths you'd want from a weapon but even the very light MS462 or MS500i that'll run 'em is 13-14lbs. The rise of electric pro saws are pretty nifty here since you can move a lot of the weight into a battery backpack. Stihl has a 50cc (MSA 300) equivalent coming this year, not enough power yet but getting close.
>>57127358
They'll cut metal and ceramic composites with the right chain, though it's a very high-wear application, 40 linear ft or less before the chain wears out. Stihl 36GBM or a custom-profile carbide chain would be good choices (wish I could run that experiment). The 36GBM even officially does 1/2" rebar.
>>57127409
Not true, works just fine for hunters quartering moose or other big game. Use quality semi-chisel skip chain like Stihl RMF for best results, and please don't ask us to sharpen it again until you've washed it.
>Stihl vs Husqvarna
My dealership stocks both. Each makes great saws, each makes some bad saws (considering the premium price). Comparison must be made on a model-to-model basis.

t. saw mechanic

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57132106
>jams on polyester
Not true of the electric saws thanks to the lack of a clutch and constant torque output. Poly chaps are still effective on small battery saws, but with the new generation of 35cc+ gas equivalents the protection becomes marginal. The industry is moving toward kevlar or UHMWPE protective apparel because of this, Clogger for example.

So begins my life's work, "The Secret History of the Tuvans." I have been selected to compose this epic because great events are about to take place. We are going to leave Tuva.

I have lived always on this frigid, dry, and endless steppe. The tribes here squabble like vultures fighting over the dessicated corpse of a marmot. We fight over limited resources: scarce water, few trees, sparse grass for our herds to graze on.

A wise and dangerous man named Shoigu means to change all this. He says that if the tribal conflict is to end, the Tuvans require but two things. First, we need green pastures for our herds. With more to go around, there will be less competition among the tribes.

Second, we are a nation of warriors; we need a common enemy with which to do battle.

To meet both these needs, Shoigu has come up with the most modest of schemes: to unite the tribes and go to war with anyone who stands in our path.

"How?" we ask him. "How can nomadic horsemen in felt tents embark on a campaign of world conquest?"

Shoigu replies that we will fight not as warriors, but as a unified army. We fight not for our glory, but for the glory of Tuva.

And with those words, the name of Shoigu has passed almost into obscurity. His name is replaced with a title: Great Khan. Genghis Khan.

>>57066320
If you like overbuilt, you could aways go for Cold Steel´s contract Demko stuff that has his designs and his tri-ad lock. Cold Steel had some pretty cringe marketing campaigns but they´ve aways made solid knives. These Demkos are not really flippers though, and you mentioned that in your first post. Another suggestion along those lines is the Benchmade Mini-Adamas in CPM cruwear steel. The Axis lock flips like a maniac and it´ll be a better finished knife than the Cold Steel Demko ones, and it has a superior, deep carry clip.

The general problem with this "overbuilt" folders is not even size, but weight. Carrying a knife in the pocket makes every single ounce count a lot. The knife tilts a lot when it is heavier. I generally stay away from folders that weight more than 4 oz. Any heavier than that, I think it is more suitable for belt carry. Others will carry an 8 ounce knife in their pocket and forget its there.

I asked if you were planning on sharpening it yourself because of your choice of steel, this is an entire can of worms with many many variables. In the most basic of terms, the higher a supersteel is rated for cutlery, the longer it will retain its edge, and the harder it is going to be for a novice to sharpen. Edge retention and ease of sharpening vary dramatically between knife steels. But even a supersteel blade will eventually get dull. This aspect must be carefully considered, and it is often disregarded. There are other factors such as hardness and rust resistance, but these don´t matter much for folders.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57067015
Like I said, cutlery steel is a big subject, and every man has his own preferences and experiences. And there is aways new steels coming, with different properties, but the market is generally oriented torwards edge retention. Every year, some new cutlery supersteel comes along with the latest and greatest edge retention. When you've been doing this long enough, you will eventually stop chasing the latest steel of the hour. I do all my sharpening free hand, and over the years I found out there is a compromise when the knife takes too many passes to get the edge back. And I know I aways end up using my higher end knives less, in favor of knives I can sharpen more quickly. Between Elmax and s30v, I prefer s30v. I even remember when it was considered the latest supersteel. Sorry about textwalling you, anon. Should be more concise

Designed by James Williams, the name is some kind of badly translated Japanese for "the sword of silence." This knife was designed for SOCOM, who requested a knife like the assisted opening Hissatsu folder, but larger with a thinner profile. It is higher quality than the CRKT M16-03Z pictured, which has a thumb stud that always seems to loosen over time. Bought for $150 from CRKT, now selling for $120 from CRKT. The Buck 110 went down in price too.

>>57098880
what you see on those Civivis is not Damasteel, but a Chinese imitation of it. real Damasteel (from the Damasteel company) is made with two powder metallurgical steels: RWL-34 (equivalent to CPM154) and PMC27 (about equivalent to 12C27/AEB-L). As good as it may look, at best it'll perform as good as a blade from only RWL34.
Meanwhile we know about the Chinese stuff that it contains 9Cr18 (equivalent to a 440B). The other steel I'd guess is something similar to 12C27.

>>57102964
Almost every custom knife maker, when he reaches a certain notoriety, stops being a true "custom" maker. They just start churning out the models they want, and these are usually already bought and spoken for before they are even made. Some many years ago, before his Cold Steel contract, Andrew Demko used to make videos himself showcasing his invention, the triad-lock. I remembered he positioned his folding knives is a support, and kept hanging more and more gym barbells against the lock. It was pretty revolutionary, really. I emailed him and asked him to make a custom knife for me. His personal email address was all around. I didn´t want anything too out of the ordinary, I just asked him to make one of his models a little bit smaller for me. He replied my email a couple of days later, a long message saying he was sorry he couldn´t help me, because he was barely having the time to make and deliver the already ordered models on his "custom" lineup. I thanked him and shortly after found a man named John Greco and he made me a folding knife exactly to my specs. This Greco man only did framelocks, though. A great knife, I wonder what happened to Mr. Greco.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57108916
>Devloped after the unprecedented success of the 110 Folding Hunter

Lol, nice way of telling that story. Heres the full story on the 112 Ranger.

So the Buck 110 was for sale everywhere, and a big customer for Buck 110s was the US Military. All branches would sell the knives in the PXs and base shops, as well as being commonly purchased or acquired in other ways by soldiers (family sending them, etc)
So Buck was making good money selling their knives to service members (119 was also very popular).
So come around the early 70s, and there is a string of fights aboard Navy ships. In some of these fights, sailors had pulled out and used 110s in the fight, and with a 3.75-inch blade, the 110 could do some serious damage.
So the Navy declared a new rule, no folding blades over 3 inches allowed on ships. So this would kill sales of the 110 to the Navy if the sailors couldn't carry the blades on ship. So I think it was Chuck Buck (can't remember 100% who was in charge at this time) decided to shorten down the 110 to make a knife that could be sold to the Navy. Thus the 112 was made, shortening the blade to 2.75-inch and coming in under the new 3 inch rule.
Buck at the time was located in San Deigo, CA. So when the knife was launched it was named the 112 Ranger, for the aircraft carrier USS Ranger that was in port at that time, the Ranger was also one of the ships involved with the stabbing incidents.

So, TL;DR is; Buck made the 112 to keep selling Buck knives to the Navy after a few sailors stabbed each other with 110s and the Navy banned 110s.

>>57126143
It actually works, consistently and reliably, hitting the specified CEP. It cost lots to develop and lots to make, and maybe/probably that included a fair amount of money padding that wasn't really necessary (lobbying, fatter profits etc). But not so much it can't be made and deployed in reasonable quantities, and at the end of the day they did enough testing and make it with enough care and attention to detail and not substituting counterfeit shit at every step of production and other corrupt crap that it actually is the real deal. To the extent there is "corruption" in American military procurement, it tends to be of the "order this stuff that you didn't really need" or "charge cost-plus for development and spread jobs out to make it unkillable politically" not "it's for parades". They get there in the end.

Of course if Excalibur cost 1/10 as much and could be made in 50x more volume that'd be legit militarily useful too, the kinds of targets to engage with it would widen dramatically. But unlike a lot of shit on the other side it does work, each and every time. So it's something tactics can be built to include and depend on. The specs are good and it hits the specs, therefore it's good.

>>57127527
It's a very long ranged rocket assisted shell in addition to being the first GPS-guided shell ever, having retractable fins that slow its rotation and stabilize and steer it like a missile in flight. I'm unaware whether it has batteries and how they're maintained but it's a very complex system, with the only things like it being showcased by euros and Koreans over a decade later.

US developed a much more elegant and economic solution in the precision guidance kit, a smart fuse that can be applied to all existing artillery shells and programmed on the go, including various airburst or delay options. It's much smaller, cheaper and retains most of the excalibur's accuracy. It's an ingenious solution and thinking about it gets me hard.

posts.com: For all the people complaining about cost, remember that more rounds means more barrel wear, more ammunition to transport, requires more artillery pieces to hit same number of tarrgets, more chances of getting hit with counter battery, more change for enemy to evade, etc.. When you compare it to a regular round, it is expensive, when you compare it to a missile or an Aircraft guided bomb, it is cheap. Also, this is relatively new production, they've already dropped it from something like 90K+ a round to 55K+ a round despite limited production. When proximity fuzes were first created in WW2, they cost nearly $750 per unit, but the end of the war they were around $20. If you apply the same reduction to the original 90K price tag, we might one day see them for 2.5K a unit, which would be completely overpowering against any conventional army without that capability..

Goddamn you dumb normies love to repeat Musk's Starlink marketing points without any understanding of it.

3000 km / c = 10ms additional ping. Orbital altitude is not a significant contributor to latency, not even for real-time online gaming. Starlink's unique benefit comes from its intrasatellite datalinks within a dense constellation. This means it always has fast routing available between any two endpoints.
If we were to imagine a scenario where all of humanity's internet traffic had to be routed through a satellite constellation, a solution like Starlink could work. It has a good architecture, similar to internet routing itself. Anything else would choke.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57133632
yes but they'll be integrated with other C-UAS options since SPAAGs are still pretty expensive even compared to SAMs. if an SPAAG is going to be really effective against UAVs it needs to have programmable airburst >30mm munitions to hit small airborne targets, an EO/IR optical targeting system to find said small targets, and maybe even a software-defined radio to detect drone (operator) signal emissions. sure, less complicated systems can be used to shoot down drones, but they're going to be limited to less range and altitude, and have issues identifying and tracking drones.

the two other big options for C-UAS are GPS jamming and electromagnetic pulse generators. the latter is especially great since it has a long range and works by damaging electronic components a drone needs to fly, so even autonomous drones with no need for GPS are vulnerable to it. but other than C-UAS, electromagnetic and GPS jammer weapons aren't very useful, unlike SPAAGs which can be used easily in anti-personnel, structure, and vehicle roles.

Literally the only thing the Reds ever had going for them were the nukes. If the Cold War had gone hot, sure the Soviets would've taken West Berlin easily and probably most of Germany in the opening weeks, but any territory they took wouldn't likely to have been held against NATO counterattacks unless under threat of nuclear retaliation, which on principle that kind of threat has to be ignored as if you allow them to threaten you into inaction with their nukes they will forever be able to use nukes to deter you to get their way. As a side note, it fucking bugs me to high hell how certain conservatives (Fox News) go on about how "This wouldn't have happened under Trump" or "Biden is trying to drag us into WW3! America is being reckless by ignoring Russia's nuclear threats!" God I hate what modern politics has become and how it's devolved into extremism, and I'm a conservative myself.

That aside, it's like how in the beginning of the Ukrainian war and how the Vatniks were so proud of how the Russians were able to invade all the way to fucking Kyiv before being halted despite not realizing that's how invasions with combined arms work in the modern era where you have vehicles capable of moving at 60+km/h, helicopters that can go 250+km/h and aircraft that can break the sound barrier. Your skill as a military doesn't come from taking territory that you've temporarily gained due to a surprise attack, it's holding onto that territory in the face of repeated counterattacks after you reach your supply chain limit. And the fact that Russia has lost over 80% of the territory they initially took before the winter stalemate took hold is testament to just how much of a failed military they are and how bleak their future in Ukraine looks. I'll keep saying it over and over, they could capture Kyiv tomorrow and it still would not have been worth it from all the supplies, men & international goodwill they've lost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57107583
The easiest way to distinguish the two is easy: the 96/11 will have a pistol grip that is grafted into the stock, whereas the Gew 1911 will have stock with the pistol grip as part of the same piece of wood. The 96/11 will have a rounded buttplate heel; the 1911 a squared buttplate. This is because they used original Model 1896 stocks when rebuilding to 96/11 specifications

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57117541
That particular screw holds the rear sight guard onto the forearm; you don't need to remove it in order to remove the forearm.
>It's also marked "D.P" in a few places up front which I read wasn't good but the barrel isn't drilled so that shouldn't matter right? Sorry for all the questions, not a lot of info online.
If it is marked "D P" on the receiver and Nock's Form (chamber area) of the barrel that's bad news; not all "Drill-Purpose"-designated rifles are functionally deactivated. If it's just on the furniture, and that furniture is not serialized to the receiver, then it may just be a "Drill Purpose" stock fitted to restore a sporterized rifle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57132714
It's very likely going to crack again because the draws aren't bearing evenly on the recoil surfaces. Note how only on the cracked side is there smooth, flattened wood compressed from recoil forces being transferred to the draws; the other side is still rough because it's not even touching the receiver properly. If you keep shooting it then the king screw at the front of the action will act like a splitting maul and the forearm will start to split vertically forward from there. The draws need to be cut out and replaced, or you do what the Aussies did and install recoil plates to take up that missing space.

>>57127687
It may have a slightly better trajectory at longer ranges, but that doesn't matter with hunting. At ethical hunting distances (400 yards and under) the better trajectory doesn't make a practical difference, and the added energy doesn't help either. With modern monometal bullets, .5mm of difference isn't going to matter in the slightest when hunting.
There is also the fact that many of these specialized cartridges just won't last in the long-run. There are already tons of tried and proven cartridges (e.g. .223, .243, .270, the various 7mms, 30-06/.308, .300 win mag, 6.5 Creedmoor, .375 H&H, .416 Rem Mag, etc.) These cartridges will reliably take any game animal on the planet. Ammo is widely available and it is easy to find bullets made for hunting in those calibers. The cartridges that last in the long-run are those that are widely adopted by the military and/or hunting fraternity. I would be pissed if I bought a rifle chambered in a flavor of the month cartridge and 15-20 years later all of the major manufacturers stopped making ammo for it.

If you're predominately a target/competition shooter, it sounds like it would be a fine cartridge. For any other purpose, there are much better options out there.

>>57080562
Dude, a housecat can slice you open enough for you to bleed to death. Maybe if it's in a rage or fear, or a mother protecting her kittens, or a moment of catness and they forget to play gentle. I've taken some deep cuts, a couple that probably should have had stitches. I know people who have had stitches.

One buddy got clawed down his arm and had about 12 or 15 long gouges about a foot long. Over 100 stitches to get all that put back together after it was cleaned very thoroughly in an emergency room. It was an accident. His cat panicked over getting picked up in an encounter with a dog and just went apeshit on him, probably confused as to who or what was attacking him. A really sweet cat that never hurt anyone, including me, before or after. But, that one incident was insane. He lost so much blood the hospital considered giving him a transfusion.

I was carrying a young kitten one day, calm & cozy & half asleep in my arms. A dog ran into the room and jumped at him. He turned into a 2 pound demon, clawed his way out of my arms, up my chest, across my face and set all his claws into my scalp when he got on top of my head. I am here to witness that hurt like fucking hell, and took a couple days of cleaning & disinfecting all he wounds to make sure they could heal instead of turning infected.

I used to do feline rescue. The feral & semi-feral cats were less dangerous because I expected it and prepared for them to freak out, and still I've taken claws and bites through heavy protection. People I know in the community all have scars to help them remember their lessons. Housecats are to be respected. Larger cats eat humans because we are under them on the food chain. It's no fucking joke. They are fast and lethal.

I mean, I'll take your word for it, but I've owned 4 cats so far, and none of them were ever aggressive toward me with their claws. Even the feral stray male that my last cat made friends with would let me pet him sometimes without attacking me.

The worst I ever experienced was with this little female cat I had (who was very intelligent for a cat). If she wanted to get my attention, she'd sit right by me and stare at me. If a minute passed without me acknowledging her, she'd put her paw on my leg or arm. If I still didn't acknowledge her, she'd then slowly sink the claws on both of her front paws into my thigh. She would straight up escalate until I finally paid attention to her. She usually did this if she ran out of food/water or wanted the litter box cleaned.

Funny story: when this female cat was still a kitten, she had a bouncy ball she'd bat around the kitchen. One time it went under the oven, so I got it out using a wire coat hanger. I got the ball out, left the coat hanger on the floor next to the over, and went back to whatever I was doing. A few minutes later, I hear something metallic moving around the kitchen floor. Turned out that the ball had gone under the oven again, and the cat was pushing the coat hanger under the oven to get the ball out. She only needed to see me do it once to try it herself. I was fucking stupefied.

She was an extremely smart and clever cat. The smartest cat I've come across by far.

>>57087541
Don't get me wrong. I love & adore all cats of all sizes. This >>57080164 is me. I cannot emphasize how much that no cat should ever be declawed. They are crippled for life, and traumatized. I've lived with cats that have been mutilated like that and it's enraging and tragic. Because I love cats so much, I spent decades doing feral cat rescue and care. The reason I can tell stories like these >>57085846 is because I've handled so many cats in so many situations. A domesticated cat that has been raised in a safe and loving environment is almost incapable of harming people. They have to be treated very badly and endangered, and many will, even then, submit to torture and death before hurting a human.

But, there are accidents. And, some cats are not taught from a young age the difference between playing and playing for keeps. That's really all I was trying to say. The potential is there, but maybe I should have emphasized more strongly how incredibly rare such things are, and how unusual the circumstances need to be for it to happen.

>>57086889
>they usually dont mean to draw blood (though sometimes they do)
This.

A training trick here that helps a lot. If you're playing with a cat and they get too rough, immediately stop moving and say "OUCH! OUCH! OUCH!" Withdraw from play for a minute or so, then start again slower and more gentle. Cats figure it out quickly and temper their behavior. If they draw blood, even a small amount, touch their nose with a drop. Just a single small drop. Every cat that's ever lived with me never needed me to do that more than twice, and usually it's only once if at all. They learn fast. Just treat them as equals and don't freak out.

>>57064486
it's common for kittens from single litters to act like that, it even has a name iirc. If you took it too early from momma cat, he didn't learn how to play properly, ie not hurt his playmate. In a bigger litter this would come naturally cause other kittens don't want to be hurt during playtime and in a single litter mother would just slap him back into obedience. You have two choices: either get a second cat of similar age, the problem solves itself and you get another /k/at or smack him whenever he acts out of line. If he is a bit bigger, which I think he is cause you've already neutered him, a moderate open palm slap on his hind legs, just strong enough for him to tumble should do the trick. If he is a smol kitten, a flick of a finger on the head to mimic the fast cat slap should be enough

Hey it's been a minute since I've been on here. To be frank I've been avoiding 4chan and /k/ in general lately just because I don't know it's been kind of overwhelming. But that's just my opinion to each their own. Anyway I am here to begin my analysis/thoughts on the latest military parade that the DPRK just conducted two days ago.

Unlike the previous threads on here I'm not going bore you with every single detail imaginable since I think a lot of you get the main picture with regard to these parades.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
>>57109738
North Korea conducted another night time parade this time to honor the 75th anniversary of the founding of the regular Korean People's Army. Last year they commemorated the 90th anniversary of the founding of the Korean People's Revolutionary Army (KPRA) which was allegedly founded by Kim Il Sung on April 25, 1932. While Kim imo and in the opinion of many historians was a genuine guerrilla fighter and a capable leader at that, he likely exaggerated a lot of his exploits when fighting the Japanese in the 1930s. Unlike his guerrilla army, the KPA which was founded on February 8, 1948 is based on authentic eyewitness and newsreel showing Kim along with Soviet officers and North Korean officials observing the founding day of the KPA in front of the Pyongyang Train Station. Prior to the rise of Kim Jong Il and Kim Jong Un North Korea seldomly had military parades. There was one parade in 1948, 1953, and then in 1972, 1985, and then again in 1992. Kim Il Sung did not seem to be a huge fan of these spectacles compared to his son and grandson.
posts.filename: Kim Jong Un waving to the crowd

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
>>57109747
Yeah my autistic niche is pretty boring I'll admit but I'll try my best to keep posting as much as I can.

Anyway skipping the history lesson let's begin the parade. Unlike the previous year in 2022 and again in 2021 and 2020, this parade has kind of been toned down in the sense that it's shorten. Perhaps this is because that the DPRK will likely want to celebrate greatly the 70th anniversary of the end of the Korean War (technically not over but major fighting ended a long time ago) and the 75th anniversary of the founding of the Republic in September.
Anyway we see the Band of the Korean People's Army and the State Merited Chorus make their way out to the makeshift stand that has been a staple of these parades since 2021. Prior to the makeshift tent, it was just an open stand but with the weather being notoriously cold in northern Korea during winter months, it is pretty good to have a tent for the orchestra and band.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Before we show the arrival of the Supreme Leader, here's a shot of the new flags of the KPA service branches. posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Now the parade has pretty much begun with the State Merited Chorus Band and Orchestra playing funky remix of "Our National Flag" followed by "Blue Sky Over My Country". Then they are playing one of the most famous songs in North Korea, "Don't Advance the Night of Pyongyang" which was the main theme for last year when the vehicles entered the square. I'm not sure if any of you are watching the video but you can notice that the audience is waving only the national flag of North Korea and not the WPK. I guess because this is army day and while the KPA is the military wing of the Workers Party, is still the national military so it figures that there would be a lot of flag waving. Also these acrobatic shows remind me of airshows I've been to in the past few years especially when they come down in parachutes while they are wearing some sort of jet-pack like thing.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: That's the main acrobatic event for now. Later there will be an airshow/fly over prior to the arrival of military vehicles. Anyway let's strike up the band. The lights have gone out and now the band master is ready to play marching music courtesy from the Central Military Band of the Ministry of National Defense of the DPRK (formally called the Military Band of the KPA).

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Some of the military music being played I can't fully make it out. It looks like it's playing "Long Live Generalisimo Kim Il Sung" but then it's playing a mixture of military marches I've never heard before. I can recognize that they are playing "March of the Guerrilla Army" as this military tattoo style formation begins to take form. The 2.8 symbolizes the date that the regular KPA was founded. This is followed by a jazzy/funky version of the band playing "Let's Defend the Party Central Committee to the End" There is also a band of drummers and some riflemen showing off their rifle throwing skills.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Rifling tosssing. I think the US military and plenty of armies do this during parades or events so it's not unique to North Korea or totalitarian regimes but it's kind of neat to see the DPRK catching up to what other military's do at parades and events.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Not the best screenshot but now we got some strobe light action following the end of the military band playing up some tunes. The main column of soldiers will appear shortly.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: The main column of soldiers are now beginning to appear with some soldiers donning winter gear on them such as ushankas and other winter gear. They kind of look like Soviet soldiers but I think its just because its winter time so of course they are going to wear Russian-style looking hats. I can't imagine how cold it must be at night in northern Korea. It is still interesting to see how seemingly modernized (its a parade so its not likely to represent all of the KPA especially the low level grunts) the KPA has gotten especially since the 2020 parade. They absolutely have done an overhaul of their armed forces no longer resembling the old KPA under Kim Jong Il and now resembles the PLA or even the Russian Military (yeah Ukraine has not been good for Russia's military image but I digress) on that. Besides there being modern KPA units there is also a column of KPA in historic uniform from the beginning during the anti-Japanese guerrilla movement to the early years of the Republic especially during the Korean War or as known in North Korea as the Fatherland Liberation War.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Here's a nice shot of a KPA sniper unit in white winter ski masks. These might be special forces. I'm not sure. In the middle of the parade columns pouring out on to Kim Il Sung Square, there is also video shots of KPA soldiers and spec ops showing off their martial arts and skills to the cameras. Very modern of the DPRK and it goes to show that this a country that is slowly but surely changing not necessarily for the better but changing in its own way.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Everyone has been assembled so any minute now Kim Jong Un along with senior officers and officials will appear at the rostrum to greet the parade goers and audience.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Now after several minutes of people shouting "Manse!" (Long Live!) with the "Song of Happiness" playing in the background we are now at the flag raising ceremony. Now this is what I am talking about when I meant there being a wall of KPA flags for the honor guard as they show up to the square carrying the national flag.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Here's a shot of the honor guard bearing the national flag as it marching towards the flag pole. As I mentioned in previous threads, since 2020 only the national flag is raised during military parades. Prior to 2020 there were two flag poles that were present at KIS Square that raised both the national flag and from 1997 until 2012 the flag of the Supreme Commander. From 2013 until 2018 the national flag and the party flag was raised in the ceremony. Now its only the national flag that is raised.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
As the honor guard approaches the flagpole, the orchestra is playing "Our National Flag" which has been one of the DPRK's most popular songs since it debut in 2019. I'll admit that I do like the song a lot since it's rare to find a DPRK song that doesn't have lyrics referencing the WPK, the Kim family or praises to it. "Our National Flag" is just a song about the North Korean flag without references to the party or to Kim.

>Our blue and red flag flies in the sky
Looking at it, the beating hearts boil with patriotic blood
In its strong flutter, the breath of the country grows
On the flag that is precious as our lives, the destiny of the people is carried
>We love our shining national flag
Flutter in this world until the end

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: We next have the national anthem played or "Aegguka" (Patriotic Song) sung by Kim Ok-ju who used to be one of the main singers in the now defunct Moranbong Band, which debut in 2012 but has since disbanded. One thing that is unique about each iteration of the anthem or military parades in North Korea imo is that they are not the same standard thing over and over again like Russia or China, it actually adds something every time meaning that every time something like this happens, the performance and the iterations change. Besides Kim Ok-ju singing the anthem, the State Merited Chorus also joins in as the flag raising ceremony starts.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
>>57110762
Eh kind of. Between 2012 up until recently they still were following Kimilsungism-Kimjongilism but now that is kind of changing with Kim Jong Un having his own cult of personality. The cult of Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il is still present, the portraits are still there and its still mandatory to have these portraits dusted and maintained well otherwise you'll get a fine by the Iminban (the Secret Police are not going to execute you for not having a portrait dusted properly, despite what Yeonmi Park claims) I think the purpose of only having the national flag is reverting back to the period before Songun (Military-First) when the national flag was the de facto supreme commander flag and was subservient to the WPK.

Anyway we got some soldiers from the period of the Korean War. I'm not sure what song is playing played as they pass through the square. These soldiers are armed with PPSh-41s which were used famously in WWII on the Eastern Front but were also very common during the Korean War. That's what happens when you listen to the same words and phrases over again when watching DPRK state media you will eventually pick up on what they are saying and some of these institutions in North Korea are known to experts on the matter so I am able to find my sources by not just listening to KCTV coverage of parades and events. posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Nice shot of the students in their air force dress uniform. These are all new dress uniforms in service since 2020 when they first debut at the October 10, 2020 parade to mark the WPK's 75th birthday. Since 2013 the KPA Air Force has its own dress uniform to distinguish themselves from the KPA Ground Forces. Until 2012/13ish the KPA Air Force uniform was basically a standard army olive drab uniform with a Kepi hat but with air force colors on their cap.

Song in the background is a famous North Korean children's song but its also sung by adults "We Have Nothing to Envy in the World" which dates back to the 1960s during a more prosperous period for the north as they were more industrialized compared to their southern neighbor though that would change in the 1970s under Park Chung Hee. The song "We Have Nothing to Envy in the World" feel sort of out of favor in the 1990s because of the famine but it has been once again a frequently sung musical piece often played at concerts and other events.

Even though Russia's military reputation has gone down the tubes especially in Ukraine, I still like their aircraft and the SU-25 is a pretty looking aircraft that is still capable of inflicting plenty of damage on the battlefield these would be used against South Korean and US forces if another conflict breaks out in the Korean Peninsula.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Nice shot of a control room with an KPA air force instructor giving out orders for their pilots as they taxi their way to Pyongyang.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Approaching the night skyline of Pyongyang. Good thing that Pyongyang though growing in size does not have a ton of supertall skyscrapers like in Shanghai otherwise they would have to be extra careful when approaching the skyline.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Don't know what he is saying here. Just thought I'd give you a nice shot of a KPA Air Force officer uniform. They have definitely reduced their peaked cap sizes to a more normalish looking one similar to the Russians though I think it looks more like the Soviet Army imo.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Alright I am back and almost ready to post the next scene of the vehicle portion of the parade. Btw I think I remember what the last few infantry columns were from. I think it would the Kang Kon Military Academy, O Jin U Artillery School, and then the Mangyondae Revolutionary School followed by Nampo and Kang Pan Sok Revolutionary School. Anyway we last left off with some shots of the Juche 107 model 155 mm SPH. Now we got some MLRS I think those might KN-09 MLRS with extended rocket tubes.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: More shots of KN-09 and KN-15 300mm MLRS.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Now some larger MLRS/short range ballistic missiles on display such as the famous KN-25 MLRS which mounted on a Czechoslavak Tatra 813 truck. Analysis says that the diameter of the rocket is 600mm making it a very extraordinary large caliber rocket launcher.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
Another screenshot of the KN-25 followed by other strategic rockets moving in.
Background song "On our March."

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
Long range cruise missile of unknown type. KCNA in the past year or so has been vague by the type of cruise missile other than just calling it a "long range cruise missile" which makes me think that this is likely just a prototype and they haven't decided what long range cruise missile they wish to adapt into service.
Background song "Our Faith".

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
Another screenshot of these long range cruise missiles.
Song in background "Long live the Workers Party of Korea"

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Now we get into short range ballistic missiles such as the KN-23 which despite its similar appearance it is not as far as most analysists can tell is not a Iskander. Externally it resembles the Iskander and the Hyunmoo-2 but the KN-23 is significantly much larger than the Russian Iskander. Similar variants of the KN-23 exist and have appeared on parades before such as in 2021 when a KN-23 variant was put on display which resembled the KN-24 nose cone.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Another closeup shot of the KN-23. Interesting to see the vehicles again sport the national flag whereas in previous parades since 2020 removed both the national flag and party flag from the vehicle masts. Looks like its only the national flag that is placed on the vehicle mast.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Final shot of the KN-23 before the grand finale the unveiling of the ICBMs. Interestingly no KN-24/Hwasongpho-11Na which externally resembles the MGM-140 ATACMS. Perhaps in July or September they will feature more of ballistic missiles such as the KN-24.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: And now the grand finale, the entrance of the Hwasong-17 ICBM, the largest of its kind both in North Korea and the largest currently in service if you don't count the Sarmat heavy ICBM.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Judging by the number of Hwasong-17 which one analyst from nknews said was a grand total of 17 ICBMs, it appears that the number of Hwasong17s have gone up in production. I counted 11 Hwasong17s compared to the previous 4 that were shown last year and in 2020.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: This the most amount of ICBMs that the DPRK has unveiled at any given time. One expert on NK news said that this was likely to show to the world that the DPRK could saturate the US with dozens of ICBMs instead of just a few Hwasong15s/17s. We don't know much about how good their missiles are but this is another example of North Korea improving its nuclear deterrence. The KCNA article even refers to it as a "war deterrent".

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: And it is still going. I wouldn't be surprised if next time they will have even more Hwasong17s. Regardless of if they work or not, it is sending a message to Washington and the world that "we are now an equal partner" in the sense that they are now a nuclear weapons state whether the world wishes to recongize that fact or not. If Pakistan and Israel and India are de facto nuke states so too is North Korea.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: Besides the 11 Hwasong17s on display there also appeared a new type of ICBM resembling both the Topol with some design influences from China mainly the DF-41

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: According to NKnews this is likely to replace the older ICBMs that were first put on display in 2012, 2013, 2015, 2017, 2018 and in 2020. This new Hwasong (let's call it Hwasong-22 since it might have began service in 2022) is likely to be solid fuel rather than liquid fuel like their older Soviet missiles.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com: One more final shot of the new ICBM with fireworks in the background with cheering crowds of people waving red flags and the national flag. And that will conclude the military parade to mark the 75th anniversary of the founding of the regular KPA. Again it was a shorter parade compared to last year but this will probably not be the only parade this year as the 70th anniversary of the end of the Korean War is going to be celebrated along with the 75th anniversary of the country's founding in September. We shall see what this year will bring for North Korea.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
>>57117890
Depends on who you ask that question. I can't answer whether or not North Korea's missiles is an enormous security risk. It's a potential one but a currently active one, probably not. Most analysts including some of our top military officials have said in previous years going as far back as 2018 that Kim Jong Un evil as the regime may be is not led by a madman but a perfectly rational actor who wants nukes for regime security to prevent it from becoming Libya, Iraq or Ukraine and to be treated as an equal on the world stage. If the world can begrudgingly accept a nuclear armed Israel, Pakistan and India the world from a realist standpoint will have to accept that North Korea is going to remain a nuclear weapons state whether we like it or not. So attempts to tell Pyongyang to denuclearize while noble in nature is just a fools errand. But to add to your question on whether or not us drone striking the parade, you wouldn't be taking out all of their strategic weapons and this missiles are likely dummy ones since it would be kind of a national security risk for North Korea to have active nuclear warheads on display. Also you could probably say goodbye to Seoul and parts of Okinawa if they are lucky enough to get missiles in the air right away. And there would be civilian deaths since those North Koreans waving those fake flowers in the background could be potentially killed.

posts.name: Autistic DPRK Poster
posts.com:
>>57117890
>>57118011
I also think its also important to note and nk news made this point as well in their most recent podcast that these parades don't necessarily represent the current state of the KPA rather it is an expression of what they want the KPA to look like in the future.

“[These] parades are really a propagandistic expression of its military plans that do not capture the actual state of the KPA’s overall readiness,”

That is what one expert had said recently. I wouldn't dismiss them as just pushovers especially since now they are a nuclear power regardless of the feelings of the world or Washington, but at the same time these parades don't capture the complete story of the KPA's overall state of readiness.

Yeonmi Park has said some things that raised some eyebrows and defectors have criticized her for making claims without evidence. For example she claimed that the color red represents capitalism in North Korea is thus considered bad. The flag of North Korea literally had red in it and the WPK flag is red and yellow. So I'm not sure where she is getting these ideas. She's gotten really popular among Daily Wire folks and those on the right. I'm not a woke shitlib or whatever but I've grown to not trust Yeonmi Park. Just because she sounds based and redpilled and talks about cancel culture doesn't make me agree with everything she has said. North Korea is such a blackhole in terms of its secrets that all we can rely on is defector testimony and while there's no doubt the DPRK is a police state and a dictatorship, but relying always on defectors when some of their stories don't make sense or doesn't hold water is not the way to go either.

She has also claimed that there is no word for "love" in North Korea. Now if the context she's saying is that there is no love except love for the leaders than sure she's kind of correct that love for the leader and the Party matters more but to claim that there is no word for "love" aka "Sarang" in North Korea when the famous song "Our National Flag" has the lyrics in the refrain, "salanghalila bichnaneun uliui guggileul" (We'll Love Our Shining National Flag) then she's wrong. She also claims that no one falls in love in North Korea, there is no such thing as romantic love in a place like North Korea. That is not true. People even in the most totalitarian societies still fall in love, have sex, get married and have kids. Marriages often happen in front of the statues of the leaders so it's kind of the cult of personality imposed even during events like weddings but this idea there is no such thing as love or romance in the DPRK is BS. I feel bad for her and what she had to go through when she made the decision to defect but lying and exaggerating just because you escaped a shitty system especially under Kim Jong Il is not an excuse to lie and make shit up.

>Aren't our viruses designed to fuck up life that evolved on this planet?
Yes. Viruses are basically hyper-specialized microscopic parasites. They are so specialized that your body probably has thousands if not millions of species of viruses in it right now, which prey upon gut bacteria and help your body's immune system maintain a healthy balance. There's even evidence that there might be viruses that prey on other viruses. Crazy stuff.

But really, the reason why Martians were so badly affected by Earth bacteria is because (according to HG Wells, whose opinions were a little dated) they "evolved" so far ahead of Humans that they had eliminated disease and the need for most of their internal organs. They don't eat, they take in nutrients directly into their bloodstream (which is retarded, btw). So because of this, their bodies had no immune system to fight off basic diseases, and bacteria just went to town.

>>57133111
energy ratio was just a bit off, but yes, DEFINITELY French
Their initial model, in typical French fashion, had this radical and weird design feature where it spun with the barrels flipped out to fire wildly in a 360 degree pattern, if you held the gun over your head.
An alternative model was also in production and fighting to be accepted that launched grenades that also acted as mines instead.
In typical French fashion, this was not immediately chosen over the autistic Blue-on-Blue-Barrage.
Finally, it saw widespread adoption, but again, in typical French fashion, they decided to nerf some of the features on the grenades being launched.
Apparently the soldiers were not keeping track of the proximity mines they were launching.
So maybe not a French thing and more of a "grunts can't be trusted with this" thing after some idiot left UXO everywhere and little timmy abdul got blown up.

Smart is not some omni-purpose characteristic like grade school teaches you. A person who has learned all the principles of Chemistry is not qualified to be a Staff Officer just because they are "Smart," and more than you would trust a Five-Star General to concoct a vat of acid because he is a very "Smart" general. Often third-world dictators get their chair by being the best war fighter. They understand a whole host of military principals and understand them well but they can still be uneducated farmers in every other way.

Gaddafi is the perfect example. He had no grasp of monetary policy, of public infrastructure or how to organize beneficial international trade. However he understood how to marshal an army and defeat insurgents. He was exceptionally good at this. I wouldn't call him smart though, because most importantly, he seemed incapable of learning from his failures and predicting his own future. >>57121009
So, you are actually talking about an idea explored in Bostrom's book on AGI. He talks about how, given access to external creation tools, it will use them to the best effect it can conceive of. I don't think it would simply just create balloons, or if it had access to an ordering system (and only an ordering system for some reason) send out a message to the firms behind the creation of the balloons to just send out balloons. Granted, he also came up with the infinite paperclip hypothesis, but he doesn't think that's possible unless the machine is extremely narrowly intelligent but infinitely powerful in terms of technological capability. It would also presuppose that the AGI would knowingly place itself at risk by allowing people to trace where the orders for the creation and then deployment of these balloons were coming from, which is an idea he explores from multiple angles and roundly comes to the conclusion that such a thing would only happen if you were able to somehow trick the AGI into willingly revealing itself, or forcing it to, as once its existence has been revealed it becomes an all or nothing scenario where it must form a singleton immediately, or risk extermination.
